docs.lead_paragraph: Updated Both at home and abroad, people are trying to move on from the problems of the past.

headline.main: The Saturday Word: Moving On, Sort Of

docs.abstract: Change is coming to Iraq, Illinois, and the G.O.P. But Tom Daschle finds his recent past is coming back to haunt him, and the way forward on the economy is murky.
docs.snippet: Change is coming to Iraq, Illinois, and the G.O.P. But Tom Daschle finds his recent past is coming back to haunt him, and the way forward on the economy is murky.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress must rectify the Bush administration’s shameful refusal to expand the State Children’s Health Insurance Program, or S-chip, to cover more low- and middle-income children.

docs.lead_paragraph: While his counterparts at other big hedge funds are trying to figure out whether they can stay in business, the fund manager John Paulson continues to rack up enormous profits. DealBook has obtained Mr. Paulson's confidential year-end letter to his undoubtedly gleeful investors.

headline.main: Few Ways to Recover Bonuses to Bankers

docs.abstract: "Shameful." "Outrageous." "The height of irresponsibility." President Obama had some harsh words on Thursday for bankers who paid themselves billions of dollars in bonuses despite the sweeping government rescue of the nation's financial industry. Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut said "every possible legal means" should be used to claw back the money. But the [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. For previous posts in his series on why the United States spends so much on health care, click here.

headline.main: A More Rational Approach to Hospital Pricing

docs.abstract: An economist proposes applying to all patients the payment method developed by Medicare, in which hospitals are paid one price for an entire inpatient episode, rather than piece-rate for individual services.
docs.snippet: An economist proposes applying to all patients the payment method developed by Medicare, in which hospitals are paid one price for an entire inpatient episode, rather than piece-rate for individual services.
